content.subtitle: Understanding how insurance protects against financial loss in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
How does insurance help transfer risk
and protect your financial future from unexpected events?

One accident, illness, or disaster can cost tens of thousands of dollars. Insurance converts that unpredictable catastrophe into a predictable monthly payment.

objectives.description: Master key insurance terms including premiums, deductibles, coverage limits, and exclusions
Recognize different types of insurance and their specific purposes
Understand how insurance fits into an overall risk management approach
Make informed decisions about future insurance needs based on circumstances

terms.definition: The amount you pay to maintain insurance coverage, typically monthly, quarterly, or annually
terms.example: In {{STATE_NAME}}, teen drivers pay approximately ${{INSURANCE_AVG_TEEN}}/month for auto insurance

terms.definition: The amount you must pay out-of-pocket before your insurance coverage begins
terms.example: With a $500 deductible, you pay the first $500 of a claim

terms.definition: The maximum amount an insurance policy will pay for a covered loss
terms.example: Auto liability of $100,000/$300,000 means max $100K per person, $300K per accident

terms.definition: Specific conditions or circumstances not covered by an insurance policy
terms.example: Pre-existing conditions, intentional damage, or acts of war

terms.definition: A formal request to an insurance company for coverage or compensation for a covered loss
terms.example: Filing a claim after your car is damaged in a hailstorm

terms.definition: The percentage of costs you pay after meeting your deductible
terms.example: 80/20 co-insurance means insurance pays 80%, you pay 20%

terms.definition: The person or entity designated to receive benefits from an insurance policy
terms.example: Naming your spouse as beneficiary on your life insurance policy

terms.definition: An optional addition to an insurance policy that provides additional coverage
terms.example: Adding flood coverage rider to your homeowner's policy

leftPanel.title: Risk Transfer Mechanism
paragraphs: You pay a small, predictable amount (premium) to protect against a larger, unpredictable loss. Insurance companies pool risk across thousands of policyholders.
bulletPoints: Premium Payment: Pay regular amounts for coverage
Risk Assessment: Company evaluates your risk level
Coverage Agreement: Policy outlines what's covered
Claims Process: File a claim when loss occurs

stats.label: Small premium vs. large unexpected loss

layoutData.title: Balancing Cost and Coverage
paragraphs: Higher deductibles mean lower premiums ‚Äî but you pay more out-of-pocket when you file a claim. The right balance depends on your savings and risk tolerance.
bulletPoints: $250 deductible: Higher monthly premium ‚Äî best if you have limited emergency savings
$500 deductible: Medium premium ‚Äî common middle-ground choice
$1,000 deductible: Lower premium ‚Äî good if you rarely file claims
$2,500 deductible: Lowest premium ‚Äî requires substantial savings buffer
Always read exclusions carefully ‚Äî what's NOT covered matters as much as what is

keyPoint.text: üí° Only choose a high deductible if you have enough savings to cover it comfortably.

leftColumn.title: Personal Protection
items: Health Insurance ‚Äî Medical expenses, doctor visits, prescriptions, preventive care
Life Insurance ‚Äî Financial support for dependents (term, whole, universal)
Disability Insurance ‚Äî Income replacement if unable to work
Personal liability ‚Äî Protection from lawsuits

rightColumn.title: Property Protection
items: Auto Insurance ‚Äî Liability (required), collision, comprehensive
Homeowners Insurance ‚Äî Property damage, personal belongings, liability
Renters Insurance ‚Äî Personal belongings and liability for tenants
Umbrella ‚Äî Extra liability coverage beyond other policies

leftPanel.title: Understanding Your Coverage
paragraphs: Health insurance has multiple cost components that work together to determine what you actually pay for care.
bulletPoints: Networks: In-network vs. out-of-network providers affects your costs significantly
Deductible: Amount you pay before coverage kicks in
Co-payment: Fixed amount per visit/service
Co-insurance: Your percentage after deductible
Out-of-pocket max: Annual cap on your costs

stats.label: Triple tax advantage with high-deductible plans
Preventive care often covered at no cost

leftColumn.title: Term Life
items: Coverage for a specific period (10, 20, 30 years)
Lowest cost option ‚Äî pure death benefit
No cash value component
Ideal for temporary needs
Good for young families with mortgages
Most common recommendation for most people

rightColumn.title: Whole Life
items: Lifetime coverage with cash value
Coverage never expires
Builds cash value over time
Higher premiums than term
Can borrow against policy value
More complex; premiums stay level

layoutData.title: When Insurance Is Most Appropriate
paragraphs: Not every risk needs insurance. Use insurance when the potential financial loss would be devastating and unmanageable.
bulletPoints: High-Impact, Low-Probability Events: Catastrophic events that would be financially devastating
Legally Required Protection: Auto liability is required in most states; lenders require homeowners insurance
Essential Asset Protection: Protecting assets difficult or impossible to replace ‚Äî home, health, income
Peace of Mind Value: The psychological benefit of knowing you're protected from financial catastrophe

leftPanel.title: Matching Coverage to Circumstances
paragraphs: Your insurance needs depend on your life stage, assets, and financial situation in {{STATE_NAME}}.
bulletPoints: Consider: age and life stage, dependents, assets owned, debt levels, health status
Best practices: Shop around, review policies regularly, bundle for discounts
When NOT to insure: small manageable losses, or when self-insurance is affordable

stats.label: Always get multiple quotes before buying
Review your coverage needs each year

scenario.name: Sarah's Surgery
paragraphs: Sarah, 28, has employer health insurance with a $2,000 deductible and 80/20 co-insurance. She needs an appendectomy costing $20,000. Sarah pays the first $2,000 (deductible). The remaining $18,000 is split 80/20: Sarah pays 20% ($3,600), insurance pays 80% ($14,400).
Insurance saved Sarah $14,400 on this single procedure.

scenario.name: Marcus's Hailstorm & James's Life Insurance
paragraphs: Marcus has comprehensive auto coverage with $500 deductible. Hail damages his car: $3,200 in repairs. Marcus pays $500; insurance pays $2,700. Without insurance: $3,200 out-of-pocket. James has a 30-year term life policy ($500K death benefit). He has two children, a mortgage, and a spouse.
Each insurance type serves a specific purpose. The right combination depends on your unique situation.

content.question:
What factors should you consider when deciding whether to purchase insurance for a specific risk?

How would you weigh the cost of premiums against the potential financial impact of a loss? When might 'self-insuring' (accepting the risk) be a better choice than buying insurance?

Which types of insurance do you believe will be most important for your personal situation, and why?

Think about your family's current insurance. What types do they have? Are there gaps? As you become more independent, which insurance will you need first?

questions.question: Explain the relationship between deductibles and premiums. Why might someone choose a higher deductible?
What's the difference between term life and whole life insurance? When might each be appropriate?
If you have health insurance with 80/20 co-insurance and a $1,000 deductible, how much would you pay for a $6,000 medical bill?
Why is insurance considered a 'risk transfer' strategy? What risks are being transferred, and to whom?

takeaways.title: Risk Transfer Mechanism
takeaways.description: Insurance transfers financial risk from you to the insurance company in exchange for predictable premium payments

takeaways.title: Know Your Terms
takeaways.description: Understanding premiums, deductibles, coverage limits, and exclusions helps you make informed insurance decisions

takeaways.title: Match Coverage to Needs
takeaways.description: Different types of insurance protect against different risks. Evaluate your personal circumstances to determine appropriate coverage

takeaways.title: Insurance Needs Change
takeaways.description: As you progress through life stages, your insurance needs will evolve. Regularly review and adjust your coverage
